Award.AwardTitle: Design and Development: Understanding the Contextual Factors that Impact Academic Change Through a Practice-Research Collaboration Supporting the NSF RED Projects

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Within the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education community, we have seen repeated calls for changing the way we educate undergraduate students. And yet, despite many years of funding and development, change in STEM education is not pervasive. The purpose of this project is to prepare faculty engaged in Revolutionizing Engineering Departments (RED) projects to make academic change on their campuses, to build and support a consortium of RED teams, and to study the process of academic change. The project team, Revolutionizing Engineering Departments Participatory Action Research (REDPAR), represents a unique practice-research partnership that links practical, applied faculty development focused on making academic change with research on the impact of contextual factors on academic change projects and the diffusion of change tactics. The project will provide a practical changemaking curriculum deployed through monthly RED Consortium calls, the annual RED Consortium Meeting, individualized consulting, and the publication of REDPAR Tip Sheets. In addition, the project includes the development of a new RED Start Up Session, a full-day introduction to academic changemaking for RED teams in their first year of funding. With the addition of the Adaptation track to the RED Program, there is an opportunity to provide specific development support to teams that are adapting existing academic change programs to their own contexts. The research will use abductive qualitative analysis through the theoretical frameworks of political opportunity theory, social movement schools, and social network theory. These findings will improve our understanding of the role of contextual factors, a key to improving change agentsâ€™ ability to predict which change tactics are likely to be most effective within their local institutional environment. The practice-research collaboration will enable both Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology and the University of Washington to contribute to the national conversation on how to make academic change happen.

While the need for systemic change in STEM higher education is clear, it has also proven difficult to achieve in a sustainable manner. Even when one department or institution has success with a change project, these changes might not be adopted by other institutions, resulting in small-scale rather than systemic changes. In order to address this problem, this research will examine how contextual factors influence the adaptation of change strategies. This research will examine how the RED teams learn from both the practice side of REDPAR as well as each other, to gain insight into how contextual factors influence the diffusion of change tactics. With regard to research, the project team will tackle new research areas that focus on the role of contextual factors on academic change projects, including 1) contextual factors that may explain variations in strategy and outcomes across the RED teams; 2) contextual factors that influence the adoption of change tactics taught by a social movement school (i.e., the Making Academic Change Happen curriculum); 3) the types of academic change tactics that are highly transferable between higher education institutions; and 4) the contextual factors that impact the transfer of academic change tactics between institutions. Our research will increase our understanding of how to leverage social networks to propagate change projects effectively. This project will share results from the research conducted with RED teams to the higher education community. By broadly sharing these results, as well as the change curriculum, we see high potential for replication by non-RED departments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to prepare faculty engaged in Revolutionizing Engineering Departments (NSF IUSE/PFE:RED) projects to make academic change on their campuses, to build and support a consortium of RED teams, and to study the process of academic change with special attention to the impact of contextual factors. Our project "The Revolutionizing Engineering Departments Participatory Action Research (REDPAR)" represents a unique practice-research partnership that links practical, applied faculty development focused on making academic change, with research that identifies important change practices that emerge in RED projects. As the REDPAR team, we have worked together since 2015 to connect research and practice about changemaking. In this project, our team accomplished objectives that link practice and research.

With regard to practice, we provided a practical changemaking curriculum that we deployed through monthly RED Consortium calls, the annual RED Consortium Meeting, individualized consulting, and the publication of REDPAR Tip Sheets. In addition, we developed a new RED Start Up Session, a half-day introduction to academic changemaking for RED teams in their first year of funding. With the addition of the Adaptation track to the RED Program, we also provided specific development support to teams that were adapting existing academic change programs to their own contexts. 

Our research during this grant period focused on three threads: search and selection of team members, unified voice and group agency, and resource mobilization.

Search and selection: We generated new insights into how academic change teams search for members, the criteria they use to select team members, and the impact of a community of practice on team formation processes. Our results indicated that search processes are informed by prior working relationships, professional networks, and the solicitation requirements of funding partners. These processes shifted over time as teams engaged with each other through the community of practice and developed their understanding of different skill sets and roles needed for their change-making efforts.

Unified voice and group agency: This line of research brought together literature on organizational change and social movements to introduce the concepts of unified voice and group agency as central aspects of team formation. We highlighted strategies and processes used to build unified voice and group agency within change teams, such as involvement of all team members, shared commitments, cohesive group identity, careful external messaging, internal trust, open and effective communication, confidence in expertise, and credibility, which helped ensure the empowerment, success, and sustainability of change projects. 

Resource mobilization: In this research thread, we drew upon literature on resource mobilization theory and social movement schools to analyze how the REDPAR-facilitated community of practice supported participants to access, develop, and leverage relevant resources. Through reflective learning processes and interpersonal interactions, change team members were able to creatively remobilize existing resources for the purposes of systemic change-making. This research thread emphasized the importance of cultivating space for change agents to engage in interconnected meaning-making and capacity-building processes.

The practice-research collaboration enabled both Rose-Hulman and the University of Washington to contribute to the national conversation on how to make academic change happen.

While the knowledge, skills, and abilities necessary to enact change projects are well-documented in the research literature, the question of how to produce widespread systemic change within STEM education remains. For even the most successful innovations, change often remains isolated in one department or at one institution. This project examined the impact of contextual factors on academic change projects to produce insights into how change agents adapt their knowledge, skills, tactics, and strategies to their immediate environments. These findings are offered to the engineering education community so we can improve our understanding of how to leverage social networks to propagate change projects effectively.

We see the broader impact of this project in the development of a growing community for change within engineering education. RED project team members are change agents and require a community to act as a sounding board, provide support, and both encourage and challenge ideas. Many change agents feel isolated, or hesitate to speak or act due to significant power differentials, thus impacting diversity and inclusion in STEM. By enlarging the community of scholars known to be engaged in change practices, the engineering education communities benefit from the improved knowledge of participating individuals. In this project, we have shared results from the research conducted with RED teams to the broader education and sociology community. By broadly sharing these results, as well as the change curriculum, we see greater potential for replication by non-RED departments. Those seeking change in engineering education can apply our work to their specific campus contexts.
